units.title: Machine-vision cell detection and droplet capture
units.text: DisCo depends on machine-vision to actively detect cells and coordinate their capture in droplets, allowing for continuous operation and enabling free per-run scaling and serial processing of samples.
units.rationale: Describes the core actionable step of detecting and capturing cells using machine vision.

units.title: Impedance measurement for input cell counting
units.text: To determine the overall cell capture efficiency of DisCo, we quantified the number of input cells using impedance measurements, which enabled accurate counting of the number of input cells as validated by microscopy.
units.rationale: Specifies a quantitative method to assess cell input, a key procedural element.

units.title: Processing low‑input cell numbers
units.text: We processed cell numbers of between 50 and 200 cells, of which 74.9% (s.d. ±10.7%) of input cells had more than 500 unique molecular identifiers (UMIs) per cell (Fig. 1j).
units.rationale: Details the experimental range and outcome for low‑input samples.

units.title: Assessment of droplet co‑encapsulation purity
units.text: We found that on average, 91.4% of all droplets contain a cell and a bead, and only 1.7% contain an independent cell doublet (Fig. 1f).
units.rationale: Provides a metric for evaluating the success of droplet co‑encapsulation.

units.title: Time‑dependent quality assessment
units.text: Given that DisCo requires a longer time period to process cells (for example, compared with the 10X Chromium instrument), we also assessed time-dependent effects on the quality of the single cell data by analyzing HEK 293T cells that were loaded on our system (at 22 °C (room temperature)) for 0–20, 20–40 and 40–60 min. Furthermore, we sampled cells that were stored for 120 and 180 min on ice.
units.rationale: Outlines a protocol for testing how processing time influences data quality.

units.title: Microvalve and machine‑vision implementation
units.text: Implementation of Quake-style microvalves22 to facilitate flow control during operation; the development of a machine-vision-based approach utilizing subsequent image subtraction for blob detection to move particles into the target region of interest with 95.9% of particles placed in a ~200-μm-wide region (Extended Data Fig. 1d); and the precise pressurization of the dropleting valve to enable accurate control of droplet volume (Extended Data Fig. 1e and Supplementary Video 1).
units.rationale: Describes hardware and software steps that enable precise droplet formation.

units.title: Generation of monodisperse emulsions
units.text: With all components operating in tight orchestration, we were able to generate monodisperse emulsions with high purity (Fig. 1e and Supplementary Video 2).
units.rationale: Summarizes the final step of producing uniform droplets for downstream analysis.

units.title: Species mixing validation experiment
units.text: We performed a species mixing experiment of human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293T and murine immortalized brown pre-adipocyte (IBA) cells.
units.rationale: Provides a concrete experimental procedure to validate cell capture and barcode assignment.

units.title: Application to intestinal organoids
units.text: We used DisCo to explore the developmental heterogeneity of individual intestinal organoids.
units.rationale: Illustrates a practical use‑case protocol for analyzing complex tissue samples.

units.title: Device channel and valve layout
units.text: The DisCo microfluidic device contains three inlet channels for cells, beads and oil; two outlets for waste and sample liquids; and several Quake-style microvalves (cell valve, bead valve, dropleting valve, oil valve, waste valve, sample valve).
units.rationale: Defines the physical setup required before executing the DisCo workflow.
